There are two questions: First, do the Democrats want to win the election? And second, do they think they can win it with this guy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OvsK41b4u4A This is not a matter of someone stumbling over an impromptu remark. Even if it were, competent people who suffer a momentary lapse can recover immediately and make themselves clear. This is also not an isolated instance. He is constantly talking gibberish, making dumb remarks, (such as calling a questioner at a town hall a "lying two-faced pony soldier"), or otherwise demonstrating that he no longer has any ability to make sense while speaking in public. In this case, Biden is almost certainly reading (or supposed to be reading) from a teleprompter, and he can't even do that. So he cannot speak extemporaneously, and he cannot speak from prepared remarks. I suppose some forecasters might argue that Biden's handlers and advisors will be running things in a Biden administration. That could be correct; we can only hope so. However, before there is a Biden administration, Biden has to actually win the election. So in my opinion, the real matter we are forecasting on this question has nothing to do with delegate counts (he doesn't have enough to win on the first ballot, and I think that the DNC will find a way to keep it that way), nor has it to do with previous elections or nominating processes. It has to do with whether the Democratic Party thinks that it can win the presidency with this candidate. Neither party has ever been in a situation where the person who is publicly touted as the presumptive candidate is clearly cognitively impaired. Maybe he will be the candidate. But there are three months until the convention, and there has got to be growing trepidation among the Democrats that they are in danger of nominating the candidate who is incoherent. Candidates who can't make sense can't win elections.

Of the people who participated in the primaries, only Warren has any appeal, at least on paper. She's a credible politician, even though she didn't do very well in the primaries, and she may appeal to some Sanders voters, who will be angry that Bernie doesn't get the nomination if Biden is thrown overboard. She probably doesn't have any real general election appeal, but that may not matter, and in any case, no Democrat really does have such appeal. Maybe so, but the original appeal of Biden was his "electability." He's a blithering idiot (as opposed to an merely being an ignoramus, which was his original niche). and with the Tara Reade accusation, he may wind up being perceived by the electorate as a scoundrel. It seems to me that every day his electability - to the extent it existed in the first place - diminishes. And if this is the case, there is absolutely no reason to run him as the candidate. I think it was obvious from the start that Biden's candidacy had no momentum or enthusiasm behind it. It was only the machinations of the DNC prior to South Carolina that eliminated all the "spoiler" candidates and mobilized the party regulars behind him in order to stop Sanders. As all other candidates have dropped out at this point, Joe Biden's nomination seems an almost certainty. The question can thus be, "What would it take for Biden NOT to be nominated?" To me there are a couple factors:
- Could Biden's health become a factor?
- Could another issue arise which leads to Biden's implicit disqualification? IF any factor becomes large enough to disqualify Biden, delegates at the national convention would have an obligation to nominate a new candidate. Given the extreme rarity that a presumptive nominee becomes disqualified in a matter of months, I'm assigning a 99% likelihood to Biden's nomination. With the additional one percent, I designate that toward "someone else" because the cumulative chance that any other person ends up the nominee is stronger for any individual listed.

I feel it's very likely it will be Biden with the majority of candidates now behind him, but there's always the outside chance of something happening to Joe Biden or him acting in a disqualifying way.

Predictit.org's Democratic Primary contract is currently selling at 83¢ best offer price for Joe Biden and 14¢ best offer price for Bernie Sanders (https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/3633). I am going to assume that these prices directly equate to the market's prediction of the probability of the candidate winning. 538's Primary Model predicts an 89%/2% chance of Biden/Sanders winning a majority of pledged delegates (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/). GJ Open predicts 80%/20% chance for Biden/Sanders winning the nomination. How do we reconcile these predictions? There is likely some type of correlation between these three predictions. Furthermore, the 538 model does not directly equate with the question at hand; it does not attempt to predict the nominee in the event of a brokered convention (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-fivethirtyeight-2020-primary-model-works/). A naive combination of the probabilities for Biden winning the nomination would be: (83% + 89% + 80%) / 3 = 84%
A similar calculation for the probability of Sanders winning the nimation would be: (14% + 2% + 20%) / 3 = 12% What do we do with the remaining probability (4%)? I propose we assign it to the all other candidates option. Final result: 
-Biden 84%
-Sanders 12%
-Someone Else 4%

Chances of someone dying are non-trivial. I'd love to hear what others think. A couple of angles: Let's say that 10% of the population gets COVID-19 between now and the convention. It could easily be much higher or lower. I'm going to guess that politicians are nearly certain to be exposed in that scenario given their frequent travel and meeting with so many different people every day. THis makes sense given the fact that so many prominent politicians worldwide have come down with COVID in a relatively short period. So it comes down to what fraction of the population has natural immunity.  I'm not sure how that works out but let's say 10-50% (I'll call it 25%) chance of Biden (or Trump or Bernie or Warren) getting it. In that case the numbers aren't great: ~20+% chance of a very serious illness involving a hospital stay that could last weeks. That would be a really serious blow to his nomination even if he had the most delegates.  Also, given his age, there's a 5-10% chance of death. So you add those up and you get something like a 
~7.5% = ~5% + 2.5%.  In that case it would be hard to argue against Bernie, and he could win outright if Biden gets sick soon. More likely it would lead to a contested convention. Bernie's probably at higher risk. Warren maybe somewhat lower. Trump about the same. I certainly don't think it makes sense to put Biden at 100% on this question as a few smart people have.  What do others think?  @Wildwood2000 @Anneinak @pstamp @Joseph-Noko

What I like about how their latest model works (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-fivethirtyeight-2020-primary-model-works/) is how nuanced it is, and honest about all the complexity and uncertainty involved.  They do clarify that their model only projects delegate counts, and not any maneuvering that may happen at the convention. I can imagine the party machine trying to keep Sanders out but I don't know how to quantify the effect of that at this point. So I'm happy to keep tracking their analysis unless I see anything more persuasive.

Frontrunners even in the Jan (and earlier) polls, going back to the 1950s, don't win the election as often as you might expect. Feb polls, on the other hand, typically get it right (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/the-democratic-primary-how-much-does-being-an-early-frontrunner-matter/). Since 2004, every leading candidate in the Feb polls won the nomination. Feb polls are out, Bernie has a double digit lead, and looks ready to steamroll his way through Super Tuesday (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-what-our-forecast-says-about-every-super-tuesday-state/?cid=taboola_rcc_r). Tempted to halve Biden, Bloomberg, and Buttigieg, and raise Bernie up to 80%+, but this scares me: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/?ex_cid=rrpromo. Brokered convention seems unlikely to me, especially as more candidates drop out, but if it happens, there's no denying that Sanders chances of winning are hurt by the possibility.

The 2020 Democratic Nominee is decided by a) having 50%+1 delegates pledged from the primaries or b) by a brokered convention given no one gets to 50%+1. Ever since primaries are held, only 2 conventions have been brokered, out of 34. Only in the 1952 Democratic Convention did the nominee with the largest plurality not get the nomination. So the base rate for the candidate with the most support to get to the convention has a 97% chance of getting the nomination. The website 538 estimates Bernie Sanders to get a plurality of pledged delegates at 70% today. That gives us hence 70% * 97% = 68% chance of Sanders being the nominee Bloomber has 11% on 538, that makes 11% chance of getting the nomination, with Warren nabbing the residual 2%
Biden has a 17% chance of getting a plurality of delegates, so that's 16% chance of getting the nomination via delegates. On the one occasion where the candidate with the most delegates did not get the nomination, the second candidate with the most delegates did. So we add that 3% left to Biden: 19% chance

My forecast presumes a 'delegate majoritarian' system at the DNC. However, there is talk of a 'brokered' convention, which seems to mean that the nominee will NOT be the one with a majority of delegates come convention time, rather, the nominee will be 'brokered' or negotiated (like 'horse-trading'). In the former case, it is difficult to see how Bernie's momentum and popularity can be equaled or bested by any other contender. In the latter case, Bernie (the 'democratic socialist') scares the Democrat establishment (almost as much as he scares the mainstream GOP and Wall St. contingency)...putting enormous pressure on the establishment Dems to broker an 'acceptable alternative (like Liz Warren*, who declared herself a 'capitalist' during the debate); a DNC 'coup' could end up nominating Biden/Bloomberg (perhaps as a ticket). So, I may have to revisit this forecast as the political currents solidify (probably after the S. Carolina primary, where Biden is supposed to retake his lead among minority voters).  *Both Bernie and Liz have some modest-to-decent support (and name recognition) in many minority communities; whether this can out-match Biden's support among black voters (esp. in the South) remains to be seen.
